conversations: What Is Depression?
Depression is a common and serious medical illness that negatively affects how you feel, the way you think and how you act.
Fortunately,it is also treatable.

Depression causes feelings of sadness and/or a loss of interest in activities you once enjoyed. It can lead to a variety of emotional and physical problems and can decrease your ability to function at work and at home.

What is Depression?

DepressionÂ is a mood disorder that causes a persistent feeling of sadness and loss of interest. Also called majorÂ depressiveÂ disorder or clinicalÂ depression, it affects how you feel, think and behave and can lead to a variety of emotional and physical problems.
What are the causes of depression?

It's complicated, and there are multipleÂ causesÂ of majorÂ depression. Factors such as genetic vulnerability, severe life stressors, substances you may take (some medications, drugs and alcohol) and medical conditions can affect the way your brain regulates your moods.
What are the top causes of depression?
Abuse. Past physical, sexual, or emotional abuse can increase the vulnerability to clinicalÂ depressionÂ later in life.

This number represented 7.1% of all U.S. adults. TheÂ prevalenceÂ of majorÂ depressiveÂ episode was higher among adult females (8.7%) compared to males (5.3%). TheÂ prevalenceÂ of adultsÂ withÂ a majorÂ depressiveÂ episode wasÂ highestÂ among individuals aged 18-25 (13.1%).
Which country has the highest rate of depression?
The most depressed country is Afghanistan, where more than one in five people suffer from the disorder. The least depressed isÂ Japan, with a diagnosed rate of less than 2.5 percent.
Which country has the lowest rate of depression?
The most depressed country is Afghanistan, where more than one in five people suffer from the disorder. The least depressed isÂ Japan, with a diagnosed rate of less than 2.5 percent.
Is school a cause of depression?

Not onlyÂ does schoolÂ sometimes contribute toÂ depression,Â depressionÂ can also interfere withÂ school. Moreover, research shows that 75 percent of all mental health conditions begin by age 24. Hence, the college years are a critical time for understanding and talking about teen mental health.
What is the biological cause of depression?

There is no singleÂ causeÂ forÂ depression; rather it's a combination of stress and a person's vulnerability to developingÂ depression. The predisposition to developingÂ depressionÂ can be inherited. OtherÂ biological causesÂ forÂ depressionÂ can include physical illness, the process of ageing and gender.
How does depression affect the world?

DepressionÂ is a leadingÂ causeÂ of disability worldwide and is a major contributor to the overallÂ globalÂ burden of disease. More women are affected byÂ depressionÂ than men.Â DepressionÂ can lead to suicide. There are effective psychological and pharmacological treatments for moderate and severeÂ depression.
Which race has the highest rate of depression?

Major depression was most prevalent amongÂ HispanicsÂ (10.8%), followed byÂ African AmericansÂ (8.9%) andÂ WhitesÂ (7.8%). The odds of depressive disorders among olderÂ HispanicsÂ were 44% greater than amongÂ WhitesÂ (OR = 1.44; 95% CI = 1.02, 2.04), representing a significantly greater prevalence of major depression.
What is the meaning of anxiety and depression?

DepressionÂ andÂ anxietyÂ disorders are different, but people withÂ depressionÂ often experience symptoms similar to those of anÂ anxietyÂ disorder, such as nervousness, irritability, and problems sleeping and concentrating. But each disorder has its own causes and its own emotional and behavioral symptoms.
Does oversleeping cause depression?
It's important to remember thatÂ oversleepingÂ is a possible symptom ofÂ depressionÂ and thatÂ oversleepingÂ doesn'tÂ cause depression. But itÂ canÂ exacerbate and worsenÂ depression symptoms
Can lack of sleep make you feel sad?

Studies showÂ peopleÂ who areÂ sleepÂ deprived report increases in negative moods (anger, frustration, irritability,Â sadness) and decreases in positive moods. And sleeplessness is often a symptom of mood disorders, such as depression and anxiety.

If you haveÂ diabetesÂ â€” either type 1 or type 2 â€” you have an increased risk of developingÂ depression. And if you'reÂ depressed, you may have a greater chance of developing type 2Â diabetes. The good news is thatÂ diabetesÂ andÂ depressionÂ can be treated together.
Can low blood sugar cause suicidal thoughts?

The observed association between plasmaÂ glucose levels, insulin resistanceÂ and suicidalÂ behaviour suggests that disturbances inÂ glucoseÂ metabolism are associated withÂ suicidal ideation andÂ attempts.
How long can Anxiety last?

Anxiety attacksÂ usually peak withinÂ 10 minutes, and they rarely last more thanÂ 30 minutes. But during that short time, you may experience terror so severe that you feel as if you're about to die or totally lose control.
What are the stages of anxiety?
Anxiety levelsÂ are typically classified by the level of distress and impairment experienced into four categories namely, mildÂ anxiety, moderateÂ anxiety, severeÂ anxietyÂ and panic levelÂ anxiety.
At what age does anxiety peak?
AdultsÂ agesÂ 30 to 44 have the highest rate ofÂ anxietyÂ of thisÂ ageÂ group, with around 23% of people thisÂ ageÂ reporting anÂ anxietyÂ disorder within the past year.
Why is anxiety bad for you?

AnxietyÂ disorders can cause rapid heart rate, palpitations, and chest pain.Â YouÂ may also be at an increased risk of high blood pressure and heart disease. IfÂ youÂ already have heart disease,Â anxietyÂ disorders may raise the risk of coronary events.
What is the 3 3 3 rule for anxiety?

There's anÂ anxiety-reducing technique called grounding. There are different versions of this, but an easy one to remember is theÂ 3-3-3 rule. Mentally noteÂ threeÂ things you see,Â threeÂ sounds you hear, and then moveÂ threeÂ parts of your body. This exercise can help your mind refocus on something else.
Do we control our thoughts?

WeÂ are aware of a tiny fraction of theÂ thinkingÂ that goes on inÂ our minds, andÂ we can controlÂ only a tiny part ofÂ ourÂ consciousÂ thoughts. The vast majority ofÂ our thinkingÂ efforts goes on subconsciously. ... Slips of the tongue and accidental actions offer glimpses ofÂ ourÂ unfiltered subconscious mental life.
How many thoughts a day do we have?

A new study has suggested that an average person has 6,200Â thoughtsÂ perÂ day. Thousands ofÂ thoughtsÂ cross our mind through theÂ day.Â ManyÂ people even complain that they can't sleep immediately after going to bed as their brainÂ doesÂ not stop thinking.
